item.title: "Has caused extreme damage to our brand and our company reputation" - Running with Scissors cancels Postal: Bullet Paradise over AI-generated assets..
item.content:encoded:
"Our trust in the development team is broken."

After receiving pushback for its flagrant use of generative AI, Postal: Bullet Paradise has been cancelledâ€¦ just two days after being revealed.

In a statement from publisher Running With Scissors, the company said the reception to Postal: Bullet Paradise - a co-op "bullet-heaven" first-person shooter from developer Goonswarm Games - had "caused extreme damage" to its brand and reputation.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

"We've been overwhelmed with negative responses from our concerned Postal Community," Running with Scissors founder Vince Desi stated today.

The "strong" feedback the publisher recieved said much of the game appeared to have been made using generative AI. "We've always been, and will always be, transparent with our community," Desi continued, adding the publisher's trust in the development team had been "broken".

As such, Running with Scissors has "killed the project", which would have seen players taking on the mantle of one of the Dudes from across the Postal multiverse.

"Since forming Running With Scissors in 1996, we've always said that our fans are part of the team. Our priority is to always do right by the millions who support the Postal franchise. We are grateful for the opportunity to make the games we want to play, and will continue to focus on our new projects and updates coming in 2026 and beyond," the founder closed.

"We can't wait to share more!"

Postal: Bullet Paradise was announced on 3rd December, with a PC release planned for 2026, before an arrival on PlayStation and Switch consoles.

Running with Scissors' decision to cancel Postal: Bullet Paradise comes as more and more companies are using AI technology. Recent examples include NPC conversations like those in the newly-released Where Winds Meet.

Meanwhile, just yesterday, Supertrick Games - the developer of Let it Die sequel Inferno - released a statement, after its own use of AI caused a bit of a stir earlier in the week.

item.title: "It's totally nonsensical!" Final Fantasy 14 composer's dream comes true, as game gets collaboration with Rage Against The Machine's Tom Morello
item.content:encoded:
It's an "absolute rocking banger of a track".

Rage Against The Machine guitarist Tom Morello has written a new song for Final Fantasy 14, making composer Masayoshi Soken's dreams come true.

The MMORPG has long had a heavy influence of rock music in its score. Jason Charles Miller, lead vocalist and guitarist of the band Godhead, lent his vocals to the game, singing Endwalker's iconic song Close in the Distance (a personal favourite), while the game's developers themselves have formed a rock band called The Primals.

Earlier this year, I asked the game's composer why he leans on rock music for inspiration. "Battle content really matches well with rock music," he said. "Musically, rock is something that is easy to hype up to, and it's also easy to understand, even though rock is not necessarily the only thing that would get you excited. I just think, as a genre, it's very easy to get involved in."

What's more, Soken told me Rage Against The Machine is his favourite band, so this collaboration is very much a full circle moment.

"It all started when Jason Charles Miller told me that Soken-san, the composer of Final Fantasy 14, was a huge Rage Against The Machine fan and wanted to collaborate," said Morello in a video message shared on social media.

"So I got down to work and wrote this trackâ€¦with Beartooth, a great band. We wanted to make something super heavy and super powerful for Final Fantasy 14. I wanted to make an absolute rocking banger of a track that would mirror the energy and the potency of this game."

Light it up, let's go! ðŸ”¥

A new song by award-winning guitarist Tom Morello, featuring Beartooth, is making its way onto the Arcadion stage in FFXIV!

Here's a message from Tom and a preview of the upcoming track, Everything Burns! pic.twitter.com/1htLXi2V1c

â€” FINAL FANTASY XIV (@FF_XIV_EN) December 5, 2025

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Soken shared the post himself, calling it "nonsensical" - he's clearly very excited.

"To write it in an easy-to-understand way? Suddenly, a song gets sent from my top fave, and it gets implemented in the game - that's the flow, and even as I'm writing this now, it's totally nonsensical!" he said (via machine translation).

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

The track, called Everything Burns, will feature in the Arcadion battle arena. It'll also be available on streaming services from 17th December. Before then, you can hear a snippet in both the social posts and trailer above.

The next update for Final Fantasy 14, Patch 7.4, will be added on 16th December. Called Into The Mist, it will lift restrictions on glamouring outfits in addition to extending the game's story.
